Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is caught stealing snacks at a store, and the father needs to handle the situation
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Design documents are due soon and other teams are waiting for their technical input
Story:
I was standing in the fluorescent-lit aisle of the grocery store, my son’s small hand clutching a candy bar he hadn’t paid for. The store manager’s stern gaze bore into me, and I felt the weight of expectation settle on my shoulders. As a father, I knew I had to teach him right from wrong, to guide him with patience and discipline. My heart ached at the thought of his shame and confusion, but I couldn’t let this moment pass without addressing it.

At the same time, my phone buzzed relentlessly in my pocket—Slack notifications piling up. The design documents for our new feature were due by the end of the day, and the other teams were waiting for my technical input. I could almost hear my manager’s voice, reminding me of the importance of collaboration and timely delivery. My mind raced, torn between kneeling down to talk to my son and ducking outside to join the urgent call. The pressure from both worlds pressed in, and I stood frozen, caught between the father my son needed and the developer my team depended on.
